column3: Definition
column4: Example

column3: a thing belonging or appropriate to a period other than that in which it exists, especially a thing that is conspicuously old-fashioned
column4: the town is a throwback to medieval times an anachronism that has survived the passing years

column3: not important or well known
column4: Marketers worry that their ads will linger unseen in obscure slots

column3: quality of seeming reasonable
column4: there aren't much evidences that support the plausibility of the theory

column3: lack of depth
column4: we ignored the news case because of its superficiality

column3: the highest point in development
column4: the artist was at the apotheosis of his career

column3: emphasize
column4: the need for fire detectors in cargo bays was underscored by some accidents in the 1980s.

column3: abstinence or restricting oneself from alcoholic drink
column4: export of spirits was hampered by the temperance movement

column3: fame or acknowledged superiority within a particular field
column4: her eminence in cinematography

column3: excited, confused or disorderly
column4: a tumultuous crowd

column3: lucky; occurring at a favourable time
column4: Sam's dangerous and providential escape made her tremble

column3: dependent on chance; uncertain
column4: Yet London's position is more precarious than it feels. The city's success over the past quarter-century has been the consequence of historical accident and good policy.

column3: refraining from an activity
column4: Sarah knows that alcoholism runs in her family. That's why she's chosen to be totally abstinent from alcohol.

column3: harshly constant
column4: the relentless heat of the desert

column3: a small group of people with shared interests or tastes
column4: He rules through a tight coterie of loyal aides

column3: constantly; always
column4: ranch meals are invariably big and hearty

column3: compete eagerly with someone in order to do or achieve something
column4: the athletes vied for a place in the British team

column3: ridiculous
column4: a preposterous attempt to turn back the pages of history

column3: working in a subtle but destructive way
column4: Plaque is insidious: we cannot see it, but each day it eats away at our enamel, causing cavities and other dental problems.

column3: hands on hip and elbows pointed outwards
column4: she stood with her arms akimbo, frowning at the small boy

column3: pretend; fake
column4: He feigned that he was ill

column3: request earnestly
column4: we implored him to reconsider his decision

column3: servile follower
column4: lackeys were waiting to help them from the carriage

column3: though
column4: he was making progress, albeit rather slowly

column3: reluctantly or resentfully
column4: I grudgingly accepted his apology

column3: over confident
column4: hope I won't be considered presumptuous if I offer some advice

column3: not feeling shame or regret
column4: she has remained impenitent of her mistake

column3: former
column4: the erstwhile president of the company

column3: persistently avoid or ignore
column4: he shunned fashionable society

column3: something that announces or signals a future event
column4: witch hazels are the harbingers of spring0

column3: predicting future
column4: his warnings proved prophetic

column3: full of; widespread
column4: speculation ran rife that he was an arms dealer

column3: to form a theory without firm evidence
column4: my colleagues speculate about my private life

column3: demanding accuracy
column4: Though his childhood piano teacher was so exacting, Max is thankful now, having become a professional pianist.

column3: abundant in supply or quantity
column4: with copious food and water the chickens will survive this winter

column3: damaging
column4: she launched a scathing attack on the prime minister

column3: with careful attention to details
column4: Overconfident students may understand how to solve math problems but not be meticulous in their calculations, resulting in wrong answers.

column3: harsh in tone
column4: Most movie critics are�acerbic�towards summer blockbusters, often referring to them as garbage.

column3: lacking excitement or variety; boring
column4: After one year in this office, the job has started to become humdrum

column3: intellectual rather than emotional or physical
column4: these problems require a cerebral approach rather than just mindlessly reading through them

column3: a tendency to choose or do something regularly
column4: Hary's proclivity for practicing algorithms is what got him a job

column3: openly disregard (a rule, law, or convention)
column4: Once in a while you tend to find some inventions that seem to flout what rules we know about physics

column3: obedient or attentive to an excessive or servile degree
column4: but at the time of need her obsequious followers abandoned her

column3: worship or regard as god
column4: the crowed almost deified the captain for winning a round that everyone thought was lost

column3: pleasant; suited
column4: this office at home has proved to be quiet congenial for me

column3: talkative
column4: despite her shy nature, once she had a few drinks her loquacious self managed to grab attention of many people at the bar

column3: feeling or showing caution about possible danger or problems
column4: Loki's reputation has made his friends wary of him

column3: wrong or inaccurate name or designation
column4: The name Greenland is a misnomer because most of the land there is covered in white snow.

column3: guided by practical experience and observation rather than theory
column4: critical reasoning requires a pragmatic approach of evaluation of the topic

column3: given to sudden change in behaviour or mood
column4: It is the capricious weather at the high altitude that accounts for the fatality rate of Mt. Everest

column3: intimidating
column4: solving these problems from the internet can sometimes be quiet daunting

column3: lacking flavour or interest
column4: months with the same food has started feeling insipid

column3: someone who spends money in an extravagant, irresponsible way
column4: She spent all her money in parties and shopping unnecessary items. What a spendthrift!

column3: strict in manner; lack of comfort or luxuries

column3: intended to teach; instructive

column3: reserved or uncommunicative

column3: extremely idealistic; unrealistic and impractical

column3: silly and immature
column4: her puerile nature of fighting over smaller things was why they broke up

column3: make someone less angry or hostile
column4: the police's attempt to placate the protestors backfired

column3: hasty and not thorough and detailed
column4: Many people including myself make the mistake of going through the passage cursorily

column3: without definitive shape or form
column4: the moon formed an amorphous reflection on the surface of the lake

column3: large in quantity
column4: the hospitals were abound with people after the government declared free vaccination

column3: someone who dislikes humankind
column4: it wouldn't be inappropriate to call Chris a misanthrope. After all, he desired to live alone in the wild

column3: similar in kind; alike

column3: clearly visible; obvious
column4: it was conspicuous that Sharon had no intentions to return the money she had lent

column3: fail to fulfill or justify (a claim or expectation); hide something

column3: catch attention; captivate

column4: Richard was determined that he did not want the decadent life his father's will had left him

column3: to make something more conspicuous or noticeable

column3: to refrain oneself from doing something

column3: to validate or confirm a statement
column4: without the witness there is no way to corroborate the charges against him

column3: to attack someone's reputation with false charge
column4: he claims to have been besmirched

column3: decrease a feeling; placate
column4: the pigs would be enough to appease the beast's hunger

column4: Global warming, a clear admonishment from nature to human kind

column3: having or showing an attitude of superiority
column4: she thought that the teachers were arrogant and condescending

column3: quality of being new or original
column4: the novelty of being a married woman wore off

column3: courteous; well mannered; sophisticated
column4: they are charming and urbane

column3: believing that people are motivated purely by self-interest; distrustful of human sincerity
column4: he was brutally cynical

column3: a firmly held opinion or belief
column4: she takes pride in stating her political convictions

column3: shy; not bold; not excessively large
column4: drink modest amounts of alcohol

column3: impartial or unbiased; dispassionate
column4: the judge must always work in a disinterested manner

column3: occurring by happy chance rather than intentions
column4: missing my trained turned out to be rather fortuitous since I met my childhood friend on the next train

column3: improper

column3: not proper or appropriate
column4: he acted in an unseemly manner

column3: controversy

column4: the needs and aspirations of people

column3: selfless concern for the well being of others
column4: some may choose to work with vulnerable old people out of altruism

column3: to admit; acknowledge
column4: eventually she conceded that she over reacted

column3: given to sudden change; capricious
column4: celebs try to appeal to the increasingly fickle public

column3: deceptively pleasing
column4: almost every image on the tv is specious and is not to be trusted

column3: difficult to catch or find or remember
column4: success will ever more be elusive

column3: ecstatically happy
column4: after the concert, I felt elated

column3: a strict disciplinarian
column4: Our care taker could not tolerate disobedience. She was a martinet

column4: the tyrant was deposed by popular demonstrations

column3: moral sense of right and wrong
column4: he had a guilty conscience about his desires

column3: spreading widely through an area or a group of people; rife

column3: excessive display of wealth and luxury

column3: unusual and distinctive nature; peculiarity
column4: she believed in singularity of all traditions

column3: to render something poorer by adding another substance; degrade
column4: the brewer is said to adulterate his beer

column3: someone who publicly recommends or supports a particular cause or policy

column3: increase power, wealth or reputation
